body:
I can definitely reproduce the CTRL-O and CTRL-S dialog repainting issue in Atom on a Win2k8 Server VM that has only basic windows theme support.

For me on Windows 8.1 the window does repaint when the dialogs are open in Atom and they are moved around. I did not mess with the windows theme so I suspect as you say it may have something to do with the window compositor being turned on.

I've been researching this one for a while now and trying various things but haven't made much progress yet. Looks like we need some extra windows message processing to deal with the painting while the dialog is open. 

A cursory search on Google for dialogs and parent windows not repainting doesn't yield much as far as I can tell now a few hours in. I followed most of the trail looking and trying stuff. 

In lieu of anyone else looking I'll make another attempt at this later today.

There are stranger things that can happen besides non-repainting.

The open/save dialog blocks user input on its parent window, if it has one.  I can open another dialog on another window, but in that case, the two showOpenDialog calls are happening on the same main thread of the browser process, with the later call nested within the first call on the stack.  I'm able to control both dialogs, though, so the earlier dialog can't possibly return until the second one has!

For example:
1. In Atom, open two windows.
2. In Window 1, select "File -> Open File..."
3. In Window 2, select "File -> Open File..."
4. Back to Window 1, choose a file and close the dialog.  Nothing happens.
5. Back to Window 2, cancel the dialog.
6. The chosen file is now opened in Window 1.

Is the node event loop supposed to be reentrant?

It looks like Windows' open/save dialogs are always modal/synchronous.  Since we can reasonably have two calls running concurrently (with two different parents, or with no parents), a proper fix is going to require running them on another thread/process, AFAICT.

> The open/save dialog blocks user input on its parent window

The open/save dialogs on Windows are modal and block user input on its parent window until the dialog is closed.

I've tried to reproduce the following steps but am not seeing the same behavior. I'm using Atom 0.143. What version are you using?
1. In Atom, open two windows.
2. In Window 1, select "File -> Open File..."
3. In Window 2, select "File -> Open File..."
4. Back to Window 1, choose a file and close the dialog. Nothing happens.
5. Back to Window 2, cancel the dialog.
6. The chosen file is now opened in Window 1.

I was using Atom 0.141.0.  I upgraded to Atom 0.144.0, and I see the same problems.  I'm using Windows 7 Ultimate SP1 32-bit inside a VM, with the Basic (non-Aero) theme.  When I tested, I opened the second Atom window using "File -> New Window...", but it looks like starting atom.exe a second time has the same effect -- the second instance signals the first instance and quits.

If it wasn't clear in my instructions, for step 4:
    4. Back to Window 1, choose a file and close the dialog. Nothing happens.
By "choose a file and close the dialog," I mean select a file and click Open.  It should open the file, but instead the dialog closes and nothing happens.  The file is not opened until Window 2's dialog is closed.

If there's still difficulty reproducing the problem, I could probably make a short screencast demoing the bug.
Okay, I have a VM running Win2k8 with the basic theme. I'll see if I can reproduce it on that one. When I tried last night I couldn't reproduce the behavior on Windows 8.1.
I think this new issue should be broken out into a separate one since it's different from the dialog parent repainting issue.

> since it's different from the dialog parent repainting issue.

Pedantic: It's not just the dialog's parent.  None of the Atom-owned windows repaint correctly.

> I think this new issue should be broken out into a separate one since it's different from the dialog parent repainting issue.

Maybe? I'm hesitant to split off an issue, because I feel like there's a single root problem with different consequences.  The root problem seems to be: we're running a modal dialog on the main browser process thread, which is responsible for multiple windows and normally runs the Node/libuv event loop.

FWIW, I have another test case that uses the synchronous version of the open dialog on Xubuntu 14.04 to demonstrate both non-repainting and an "X Window System error" that crashes the program.
Okay, I was definitely able to reproduce the dialog open/two editor windows issue after you reexplained it. That is pretty wild!

Okay after further tests on two systems one running Windows 8.1 and the other is a Win2k8 VM. I get inconsistent results. I definitely was able to reproduce what you said but now I'm not able to. The dialog boxes on multiple windows do affect each other but what happens for me almost all of the time is that one dialog on one window will hang the other but the files load properly in the respective window almost all of the time. Since I last posted an hour ago I was not able to get a file to load in the wrong window using the steps.

I cannot comment on the threading issues so I've been looking at file_dialog_win.cc and trying various things and Googling and none of which have completely resolved the issue. I'd like to see what @zcbenz has to say about this particular issue.

On Windows file dialogs were run synchronously no matter whether a callback was specified, and screen painting was blocked by this. There should be a way to make them run asynchronously, since Chrome runs all dialogs asynchronously.

I spent a number of hours on this. I kept stumbling around trying stuff.and
I was specially looking at file_dialog_win.cc and Googling to no avail. I
was thinking that the call to the dialog show function with it's parent was
the problem. I tried some other Win32 calls to grab either the desktop
window or the parent window instead of the window that was specified and
was able to get some different results but not solve the issue. There is
some crazy stuff going on especially when multiple Atom windows with open
and/or save dialogs are open in each. The results are crazy. Definitely
broken in my opinion.

I believe Chrome makes file dialogs asynchronous on Windows by running them on a separate thread or process.

For example, I grepped Chromium for `GetOpenFileName`, and I found code in `src/ui/shell_dialogs` that creates a new thread for each dialog opened.  The code talks about a "UI thread" versus a "dialog thread".  The new dialog thread is created in `BeginRun`.  Chromium has code to disable the owner window, by hand, presumably to aid in synchronization:
- https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/master/ui/shell_dialogs/base_shell_dialog_win.h
- https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/master/ui/shell_dialogs/base_shell_dialog_win.cc
- https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/master/ui/shell_dialogs/select_file_dialog_win.cc
